in North Africa, the Sahel, the Mediterra-

. Thus, the direct forcing patterns in Fig. 5a and

. Over water, the cooling is strongest
in the tropical North Atlantic and over the Arabian Sea. In the

resulting in a southward shift of the Intertropical Convergence
Zone, thus weakening the West African Monsoon
change in the Atlantic Meridional Mode
would both conspire to inhibit tropical cyclone for-
cation over the North Atlantic. Over the
Arabian Sea, the dust forcing would weaken the climatological
northward meridional sea surface temperature (SST) gradient and
amplify the cooling associated with absorbing aerosols emitted

lation and possibly improving conditions for the formation of
Sahara would increase the land-sea temperature gradient, which
. Indeed, it is thought that the enhanced
rainfall of the African Humid Period (AHP), which was a period
5 kyr BP when the Sahara was almost completely vegetated
and supported perennial lakes, was the result of orbital forcing
that similarly enhanced the land-sea temperature gradient
However, studies have also shown that the enhanced monsoonal
rainfall of the AHP was also encouraged by a reduction in the
concentration of dust over the continent
elevated dust layer reduces rainfall by increasing atmospheric
. Thus, the impact on the West African Monsoon
may be a balance between the partitioning of dust atmospheric
Our results distinctly include the possibility that dust loading
might increase in response to future warming (Fig. 3). This would
be opposite to the response inferred from paleoclimate, since
colder climates tend to be dustier over the last million years (e.g.,
the last glacial maximum is substantially dustier than the mid-
that feedbacks relevant on longer geologic timescales are different
than the feedbacks acting on the century timescale modeled here,
or that the feedbacks are sensitive to the initial state as indicated
backs over the coming decades to centuries is not well con-
strained by paleoclimate feedbacks over the last million years.
Although it remains an open question whether global dust
loading will increase or decrease in the future, our results suggest
that current climate models might underestimate the dust cycle
response to climate change. In particular, we
for the additional physics included in the K14 emission scheme
enhances the sensitivity of the dust cycle to climate changes,
which might have contributed to an improved ability to repro-
duce observed long-term changes in dust AOD (Fig. 1). Speci
cally, the K14 parameterization accounts for the increase in the
ux per unit of horizontal saltation
occurs when soils become more erodible, which for instance
arises from the predicted future drying of soils on most deserts
(Supplementary Fig. 5). The net effect of accounting
for this and other additional physics is a near-doubling of the
increase in dust emissions per degree surface temperature change
(Fig. 2), causing it to exceed the range spanned by CMIP5 models
